WRITING.TITLE: Water weight or fat?
WRITING.TEXT: I've started to diet again after the shock of my life, I decided to jump on the scales in a friends bathroom.. 103 kg the highest weight I've ever been. I've always been fat but still I never imagined I would weigh over 100kg. I guess all the comfort food in winter cought up to me! So the same day I decided I would blow the dust off my fitness gear amp; start a diet. Now here's the problem it's been 2 weeks amp; I've lost 11kg (eating 800-1200 cal a day amp; a very active job with workouts at home aswell) But I feel this is far too much for such little time amp; my body looks exactly the same. I'm not expecting to be an Adonis over night but I thought 11kg would be enough to show some small progress on my body. So how to I know if I'm actually losing weight or if it's just water?

WRITING.TITLE: Not sure if crappy memes are allowed :)
Was told to post this here :)
2 months amp; going strong!!
WRITING.TEXT: So I posted here about 6 weeks ago at the start of my diet, I was so pleased I had kept it up for 2 weeks at the time. It was a major accomplishment for me to stop binge eating and start a healthier eating pattern. And today I realised it's been 2 months! I've lost 14kg so far ( pretty sure its mostly water, but still :D ) For context I've always struggled with my weight amp; after going through a depressive episode I completely let myself go. I'd binge eat all day for lack of something better to do amp; my self esteem completely fell apart To keep track of calories and not over do things I've been planning meals amp; have stopped buying all the foods I binge. I hope I can post again in 2 months and still be on track! I just wanted to share my little accomplishment amp; would love to hear about you guys triumphs #9825;

Female sexuality amp; horror cinema
WRITING.TEXT: After being an avid horror fan since childhood I feel I have a pretty good understanding of the typical stereotypes and tropes. The one that irritates me the most are the female stereotypes surrounding womens sexuality. Theres the classic slasher girls, you know the ones.. only on screen to be brutally murdered after getting their breasts out. They're there to teach the lesson that promiscuous behaviour is to be punished and only the virginal "pure" girl makes it to the end and defeats the monsters. Sex sells, and if you #8217;re getting an R rating for gory violence, you may as well throw some gratuitous nudity in aswell. (its 90% female nudity) Then there's the seductive witch/temptress/supernatural non human woman who harms men and uses sex as a means to get what she wants. This stereotype is used to tarnish female sexuality as always having an ulterior motive for wanting sex I.e the alien in "under the skin", the alien girl in "species", the witch in "the vvitch". Their motives are usually to lure men in with sex to kill, eat or reproduce with them. Because for a male director amp; assumed male audience a woman's sexuality is seen as a weapon to ensnare men for motives other than simply wanting sex. This is common place even in modern times when female sexuality has only barely been accepted for some 60 years or so. These stereotypes are very pervasive but in recent years there have been brilliant films that subvert the genre tropes brilliantly and depict women as more than objects of male desire/evil temptresses. Some of my favourites are the descent amp; you're next. What are yours?
